title: Kitfo
text:
Kitfo (, ), is an <a href="Ethiopian%20cuisine">Ethiopian</a> traditional dish originated from ethnic <a href="Gurage%20people">Gurage people</a>. It consists of minced <a href="raw%20meat">raw</a> <a href="beef">beef</a>, marinated in "<a href="mitmita">mitmita</a>" (a chili powder-based spice blend) and "<a href="niter%20kibbeh">niter kibbeh</a>" (a <a href="clarified%20butter">clarified butter</a> infused with herbs and spices). The word comes from the <a href="Ethiopian%20Semitic%20languages">Ethio-Semitic</a> root k-t-f, meaning "to chop finely; mince."
"Kitfo" cooked lightly rare is known as "kitfo leb leb". "Kitfo" is often served alongside—sometimes mixed with—a mild cheese called "ayibe" or cooked <a href="Leaf%20vegetable">greens</a> known as "gomen". In many parts of Ethiopia, "kitfo" is served with "<a href="injera">injera</a>", a flatbread made from <a href="teff">teff</a>, although in traditional <a href="Gurage">Gurage</a> cuisine, one would use "<a href="kocho%20%28food%29">kocho</a>", a thick flatbread made from the "<a href="ensete">ensete</a>" plant. An "ensete" leaf may be used as a garnish. Though not considered a delicacy, "kitfo" is generally held in high regard.
"Kitfo" is served on special occasions such as holidays; it is commonly used on the "Finding of the True Cross" or "<a href="Meskel">Meskel</a>" holiday celebrated annually on September 27 in Ethiopia.
